user_message:
An agent A claimed that the following digest_get_size code violates the MISRA C 2023 rule 1.2.
<misra_rule>
MISRA C 2023 Rule 1.2 is Language extensions should not be used.
You should report only when the code uses any language compiler extensions that are explicitly stated as an extension in compiler documentations.
</misra_rule>
<target_code>
Here is the original code of digest_get_size.
```c
_MHD_static_inline unsigned int
digest_get_size (struct DigestAlgorithm *da)
{
  mhd_assert (! da->uninitialised);
  mhd_assert (da->algo_selected);
#ifdef MHD_MD5_SUPPORT
  if (MHD_DIGEST_BASE_ALGO_MD5 == da->algo)
    return MD5_DIGEST_SIZE;
#endif /* MHD_MD5_SUPPORT */
#ifdef MHD_SHA256_SUPPORT
  if (MHD_DIGEST_BASE_ALGO_SHA256 == da->algo)
    return SHA256_DIGEST_SIZE;
#endif /* MHD_SHA256_SUPPORT */
#ifdef MHD_SHA512_256_SUPPORT
  if (MHD_DIGEST_BASE_ALGO_SHA512_256 == da->algo)
    return SHA512_256_DIGEST_SIZE;
#endif /* MHD_SHA512_256_SUPPORT */
  mhd_assert (0); /* May not happen */
  return 0;
}
```
</target_code>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- explanation: your evaluation of the scenario provided by the agent A.
- is_report_correct: whether the report is correct or not (true/false). True means there is a violation.
</response format>
<scenario>
The agent A provided the following violation scenario:
The macro _MHD_static_inline expands to use the GCC/Clang extension __attribute__((always_inline)) (i.e. uses the compiler-specific attribute syntax), which is a documented language extension — this violates MISRA C 2023 Rule 1.2.
</scenario>
<additional code>Here are the definitions of symbols that are close to the target function digest_get_size:
#define _MHD_static_inline staticinline__attribute__((always_inline))
...
#define mhd_assert(ignore) ((void)0)
...
struct DigestAlgorithm
{
  /**
   * A context for the digest algorithm, already initialized to be
   * useful for @e init, @e update and @e digest.
   */
  union DigestCtx ctx;

  /**
   * The hash calculation algorithm.
   */
  enum MHD_DigestBaseAlgo algo;

  /**
   * Buffer for hex-print of the final digest.
   */
#ifdef _DEBUG
  bool uninitialised; /**< The structure has been not set-up */
  bool algo_selected; /**< The algorithm has been selected */
  bool ready_for_hashing; /**< The structure is ready to hash data */
  bool hashing; /**< Some data has been hashed, but the digest has not finalised yet */
#endif /* _DEBUG */
}
...
#define MHD_MD5_SUPPORT 1
...
#define MHD_SHA256_SUPPORT 1
...
#define MHD_SHA512_256_SUPPORT 1
...
#define MD5_DIGEST_SIZE (MD5_DIGEST_SIZE_WORDS*MD5_BYTES_IN_WORD)
...
#define SHA256_DIGEST_SIZE (SHA256_DIGEST_SIZE_WORDS*SHA256_BYTES_IN_WORD)
...
#define SHA512_256_DIGEST_SIZE (SHA512_256_DIGEST_SIZE_WORDS*SHA512_256_BYTES_IN_WORD)
</additional code>

<instruction>
Judge whether the report is correct or not.
</instruction>
explanation: Agent A is correct. The function uses the _MHD_static_inline macro which (per the provided definition) expands to use the GCC/Clang attribute syntax __attribute__((always_inline)). That attribute form is a documented compiler language extension (GCC/Clang attribute syntax) and therefore constitutes use of a language extension. MISRA C 2023 Rule 1.2 prohibits use of language extensions, so this is a violation. (If the project had a portability wrapper that defined the macro to an empty token for strictly-conforming toolchains, this would change the conclusion; but based on the supplied macro definition the extension is used unconditionally.)
